awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will provide support for participants to attend a week-long conference on Equidistribution and Arithmetic Dynamics that will be held at Oklahoma State University during June 2022. The conference will consist of equal parts dissemination and education; that is, it will offer both a discussion of current research, and the opportunity for education in the area, bringing participants to the forefront of current techniques and research. Besides the daily plenary presentations, this will be done by including mini-courses and problem sessions for earlier career researchers and graduate students, and a particular effort will be made to recruit women and participants from historically underrepresented groups.

The topic of equidistribution is classical in Number Theory. However, there have been many fundamental advances in the study of distribution for algebraic numbers, and more generally, for points of small height in various number theoretic settings, during the latest two decades. Thus, a conference dedicated to this circle of problems is both timely and necessary. It will summarize major achievements, and will also facilitate exchange of ideas and methods between various directions of research in this rapidly developing area. There will be several problem sessions and discussion groups that will help to compile a list of problems and set possible approaches to their solutions. This conference will greatly stimulate future progress and collaboration on equidistribution problems between mathematicians from different fields and backgrounds. For more information, see the conference website  https://cas.okstate.edu/department_of_mathematics/department_of_mathematics_ead.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The conference “Equidistribution and Arithmetic Dynamics” was held at Oklahoma State University (Stillwater, Oklahoma) during June 20-24, 2022. It was devoted to several important topics on the intersection of Number Theory and Dynamics. The topic of equidistribution is classical in Number Theory. However, there have been many fundamental advances in the study of distribution for algebraic numbers, and more generally, for points of small height in various number theoretic settings, during the latest two decades. Generalizations of such results have also had applications towards problems of unlikely inter- sections in dynamical systems. The latter include equidistribution results for the generalized Mandelbrot sets, and unlikely intersection theorems for the Mandelbrot sets as well as for families of elliptic curves. We summarized many latest achievements and provided fertile ground for exchange of ideas and methods between various directions of research in these rapidly developing areas. Thus, we focused on the following three groups of problems at the conference: 

  • Equidistribution of algebraic numbers and generalizations
  • Discrepancy and quantitative estimates in equidistribution
  • Applications to unlikely intersections and uniform boundedness results 

We designed an extensive conference web page that contains a lot of additional materials, including a list of open problems proposed and discussed at the conference: 

https://cas.okstate.edu/department_of_mathematics/department_of_mathematics_ead.html

Our participants came from all over the world, including Asia, Europe, North and South Americas. We made special emphasis on attracting and supporting graduate students, postdocs, and young researchers, as well as women and other members of underrepresented groups. Having a mix of leading experts in the areas of the conference together with many graduate students and young researchers created an ideal situation for transfer of knowledge and fostering long term collaborations. The composition of our 76 registered participants, both in-person and virtual, is as follows: 

The composition of our 76 registered participants, both in-person and virtual, is as follows: 

  • 40 graduate students, including 9 women and 6 other minorities
  • 12 postdoctoral associates, including 3 women
  • 10 young researchers, including 2 women
  • 12 plenary speakers, including 2 women, one of whom is a postdoc 

Our daily schedule included two or three one-hour plenary talks given by the leading experts in the field, with the remaining time occupied by several contributed talks, mini-courses for graduate students, and problem sessions. Total breakdown of conference activities is as follows: 

  • 12 plenary talks given by leading experts in respective fields
  • 18 contributed talks
  • 3 problem and discussion sessions
  • 5 mini-courses on equidistribution and arithmetic dynamics 

The plenary talks set the tone of the conference by surveying major progress in respective areas, introducing new and unpublished results, and indicating main directions for the development. Many of our contributed speakers were accomplished researchers and well-known figures in their areas. They also presented a wide range of new and important results and proposed many open problems. Problem and discussion sessions were especially useful for exchanging by new and old open problems of great importance and for proposing ideas and approaches to their solutions. Mini-courses “Introduction to Arithmetic Dynamics,” “Introduction to Equidistribution,” “Dynamical Equidistribution Theorems,” “Equidistribution and Algebraic Numbers,” and “Resultants and Applications to Dynamical Systems,” created a special learning opportunity for the graduate students become involved into the forefront of research in conference areas.

Modified by: Paul Fili
